DOC.HEAD: First Atlantic Crossing Made By Ethanol Plane
Eds: CORRECTS spelling of pilot to Shauck, sted Schauck, in grafs 8, 9, 12, 16 and 18.
DOC.TEXT: It wasn't quite Lindbergh, but a Texas university professor earned his footnote in aviation history Tuesday when he completed the first trans-Atlantic flight in an ethanol-fueled airplane. Max Shauck, a mathematics instructor at Baylor University in Waco, Texas, landed at the small Toussus-le-Noble airport southwest of Paris after a one-hour flight from Tours. He set out with Italian co-pilot Grazia Zanin from Waco on Sept. 15 in a light experimental aircraft that carried them through often rough weather to Canada, the Azores, Portugal, Spain and finally France. ``We feel we have proved that ethanol is a very reliable fuel,'' Shauck said. ``You can't get across the Atlantic on an unreliable fuel.'' Proving the merits of the relatively cheap, non-polluting ethanol compared to standard fuel drove Shauck make the journey, which he funded himself at more cost ``than I care to think about.'' Ethanol is essentially an alcohol fuel made from vegetable matter, usually corn in the United States and sugar beets in Europe. Shauck, who also does air pollution research at Baylor, says ethanol retails for about $1.20 per gallon in the United States compared to $1.80 for high-octane aviation fuel. ``It produces more power, it burns cooler and there's a lot less pollution,'' he said. ``But we had to go out of our way sometimes to find it.'' Indeed, Shauck and Zanin's flight log includes a hodgepodge of small stopovers in North America chosen chiefly because ethanol could be delivered there. These included Paducah, Ky.; Newark, Ohio; Hazelton, Pa.; and Suffolk, N.Y. The plane also stopped at Shauck's hometown of Mansfield, Ohio. In Canada, they stopped at Moncton and St. Pierre-et-Miquelon before lifting off from St. John's, Newfoundland on Oct. 20 for Flores in the Azore Islands, a 2,000-mile crossing made terrifying by rain and thunderstorms. ``It's a long way over a lot of water when you're flying a little plane looking for little islands,'' he said. ``We didn't have sophisticated navigation equipment.'' They waited in the Azores for nearly three weeks for a shipment of ethanol to arrive before flying to Lisbon Nov. 10. Shauck, 54, and Ms. Zanin, 33, made stops in Bilbao, Spain, and Bordeaux, Rochet-Sur-Yon and Tours in France. Technically, they became the first people to cross the Atlantic in an ethanol-fueled plane the minute they touched down in Portugal, but the original plan they filed with American authorities was from Suffolk County, N.Y., airport to Paris. The fiberglass aircraft, a sort of flying wing built by the Velocity Corp. of Sebastian, Fla., featured elevators, normally found on the tail, at the front of the airplane and a propellor mounted on the back. The whole contraption weighs about 2,100 pounds and can reach a top speed of 200 mph. Shauck resists comparison with American aviator Charles Lindbergh, first man to cross the Atlantic in a flight from New York to Le Bourget airport in Paris on May 31, 1927. ``He is a hero,'' Shauck said. ``Everything now is different than it was in his day. I avoided going to Le Bourget because I didn't want to be compared to him.'' Shauck said he would take a commercial flight back to Texas, but that the aircraft will make one more trip _ to Ms. Zanin's hometown, Trieste.
